title: Every Investor Should Invest in Japan

transcript.text:
I've spent time in more than 150 countries, 
and only one of those I keep coming back to.

The country that I've returned to the most 
as a traveler is the land of the rising sun,

Japan. But just because you love a country to 
bits doesn't mean it's a good investment. Today,

I'm going to tell you why you absolutely should 
have Japanese exposure in your portfolio.

We'll look at the best ways to get exposure 
and talk about some Japanese stocks, even five

Japanese stocks that Warren Buffett has invested 
in. Everything you need to know about investing

in Japan is in this presentation, so watch it 
closely, please. You'll learn a ton. I promise.

So many American investors only have exposure 
to US stocks. That's called domestic bias and

it results in investors not being exposed to a 
good chunk of global equities, including Japan.

So where can we find a list of all global stocks 
to start with? We can turn to the leader in global

indices MSCI. Now I started working at MSCI 
while they were still part of Morgan Stanley,

and I left the firm probably nine years after 
their IPO. During that time, I learned a lot about

how these indices work. And I think every retail 
investor should have a good understanding of how

to carve up the global universe of all stocks 
in the world. And one such universe is the MSCI

ACWI IMI Index. Now, ACWI stands for All Country 
World Index. So, all countries in the world. And

IMI simply means all market caps. And basically, 
this index can be cut into two pieces. You have

developed markets and emerging markets. And MSCI 
is a very sophisticated methodology that looks at

how to assign a country into an emerging market or 
a developed market classification. And as you can

see here, this index is composed of 23 developed 
markets, 24 emerging markets. And when you combine

those both, you get 8,286 stocks. That represents 
99% of the global equity investment opportunity.

Now, just some key points from Grok here. There 
is zero overlap between developed and emerging

markets. So, a country has to be classified in 
one or the other. And when you break these down,

developed market countries, so the more mature 
countries in the world, make up about 88 to

90% of the weight of this index, whilst emerging 
markets make up the rest. So, they're a very small

component of total global equities. And here you 
can see a summary of that index. So again, 8,286

stocks, the top 10 constituents on the right, the 
usual suspects there, NVIDIA floating at the top,

followed by Apple, Microsoft, Amazon, etc. Now, 
when we take that index and start breaking it

down by country, it gets very interesting. 
So the largest country, the biggest chunk of

global stocks, intuitively, is the United States 
at around 64% of global equities. What that means

is that 36% of your equities exposure should be 
global. And the second largest market in the world

after the United States is Japan. Around 5.5% of 
your equity exposure should be in Japanese stocks.

And nearly 80% of your global equity exposure 
would be in the five countries that you see here.

US, Japan, United Kingdom, China, and Canada. Now 
this is very important to note. It's not a matter

of whether Japan is a good investment or not, and 
we're going to talk a little bit about that. It's

a matter of having exposure to global equities in 
appropriate weightings. So, anyone who has equity

exposure ought to have global equity exposure. 
And of that, 5% ought to be exposure to Japan.

Some of you may want to actively manage your 
Japan exposure either through using an ETF or

perhaps by having a small portfolio of stocks. 
The purpose of that would then be so that you

could either overweight or underweight Japan. 
And I had Super Grok pull up an overweight and

underweight thesis. So on the bullish side, 
there's reforms happening that include stock

buybacks and increased dividend payouts. So 
upping the value component there. There's also

a valuation discount here to be considered. 
So I think the Japanese stocks are around

12 times forward earnings. US stocks probably 
double that. And after decades of stagflation,

inflation has returned. So the economy might 
be turning itself around. On the other hand,

Japan's government debt exceeds 250% of their 
GDP. That could potentially be problematic. The

Yen weakness, this is remarkable. So exposure 
to the Yen by investing directly in Japanese

stocks has cost investors up to 30% in purchasing 
power over 5 years. So, I'm here in Japan now and

I just went and bought a pair of my favorite 
jeans from Momotaro, and they're the cheapest

I've ever bought them. Right now, the yen is very 
weak, and it's a great time to visit Japan. Well,

anytime is a great time to visit Japan, frankly. 
But there's also an aging population and low birth

rates which potentially pose problems. So, 
you can make a bull case or a bear case for

Japan. And after you do, you'll probably find 
that your investments there behave entirely

opposite of what your thesis proposed. So having 
a thesis around Japan isn't the focus here. It's

really having Japanese exposure because it's the 
second largest economy in the world. And when we

look at what ETFs might give us that exposure, you 
have, of course, iShares MSCI Japan ETF. And that

charges too much. They charge 50 basis points. 
And even though it's the largest ETF out there,

it's certainly one I wouldn't invest in because 
multiple studies have found that, intuitively,

low expense ratios are the biggest predictor 
of fund outperformance. So back in the day,

I was looking at country ETFs and I saw Japan, 
and it was trading at $15 a share, and I was like,

"Wow, it's so cheap." So I'm so glad I eventually 
learned that the price of an asset has nothing to

do with the value. So just because this trades 
at $80 a share doesn't mean anything at all.

Literally, it means nothing. What you need to pay 
attention to are expense ratios. Now, what we can

do then is go to VettaFi and pull up a list of all 
Japanese ETFs, and I've done that here. You can

see iShares actually has one currency hedge. 
So, I wonder why they did that, right? So,

you could hedge away that exposure to yen. But 
when we go down this list, I think anything above

this red line is fair game in terms of size. 
You always want to invest in ETFs that have a

reasonable amount of assets under management. And 
we can then flip the page here and look at expense

ratios. And clearly one stands out. It's Franklin 
FTSE Japan ETF. So that's the one that I would

invest in because it has the lowest expense ratio. 
And we can start to dig into that. Honestly,

in looking across these ETFs, in particular, the 
iShares and this Franklin ETF, there's not a whole

lot of difference in terms of constituents, but 
you'll find pictures like this. So Industrials

are quite high, around 24% of your exposure. than 
consumer discretionary. Information Technology in

fourth place there. Contrast that to the US where 
Information Technology is dominant. Then, when we

start looking at holdings, Toyota, of course, 
is on the top there. Always buy a used Toyota.

It's one of the best financial decisions you ever 
make. Start going down, and I wanted to highlight,

I mean, there's some familiar names here but 
wanted to highlight a few: Mitsubishi, Sumitomo,

and Mitsui. So these are what's called Sogo 
shosha, and they're general trading companies.

They're more or less conglomerates, but it's a 
lot more complicated than that. And there's seven

major houses. I've circled the top five here. And 
the reason I've done that is because these happen

to be firms that Warren Buffett is holding. So 
he first started investing in these companies, I

think, it was in 2019. His ownership of these has 
increased from roughly 8.5% to almost 10% across

these five firms. He says he wants to hold these 
for decades, potentially forever. So, if Warren

Buffett vetted the Japanese investment thesis and 
found these compelling, then that certainly says

something, right? So, speaking of foreign stocks, 
we recently sent out a survey to our paying

customers, and one of the most frequent requests, 
I was quite surprised, was for far more foreign

stock coverage. That's not just because half of 
our paying customers are from abroad. It's also

because US investors are increasingly becoming 
interested in foreign stocks. Now, I couldn't

be more excited to do that, given how much I 
love travel and foreign cultures. Can you say,

more exciting work trips coming up? However, in 
the past, we haven't seen a lot of interest in our

foreign stock content. So, if you want to see more 
foreign stock coverage, please like this video,

hype it. There's this new hype feature on YouTube 
now. You can avail yourselves of that, please. And

share this video with your friends. And in return, 
I'll plan on doing more of this type of content

going forward because it's what our bosses want. 
Maybe a piece on Japanese tech stocks, right? So,

let me know in the comment section what you think 
about that. So, let's touch on Japanese tech

stocks for a second. I saw this question raised 
recently. Is innovation in Japan all just a big

sticktick? I can tell you that nobody innovates 
like the Japanese when it comes to a household.

It's insane how well they've figured out 
innovation. But the counterpoint would be, well,

that's all just a ruse and that proper innovation 
is quite stale. That would merit a further look,

I think. Now, if you want to start investing in 
Japanese stocks, well, you're in for a real treat.

And when I worked for MSCI, I always needed to 
staff. So, I was in the Hong Kong office, I always

needed to staff a Chinese person that could speak 
Japanese. And then when we started porting over

some of our operations to Manila, we specifically 
hired Japanese speakers there, which were tough

to find. And we had to keep them on staff because 
it was impossible for us to navigate the world of

Japanese stocks without having native speakers. 
This isn't just about, you know, converting yen

to USD or figuring out how to navigate some of the 
most shoddiest investment collateral mankind has

ever seen. The biggest problem is that you can't 
Google translate your way through it at all. This

blog had popped up, Engrish.com. It's a collection 
of all the different things the Japanese say that

are quite comical and endearing. They try to 
literally translate English a lot of times and

it's just a complete and total mess. Some of my 
more favorite ones, they used to rank them at this

site. One is a Japanese gentleman with a Christmas 
shirt that says "crap your hands." Right? Supposed

to be clap your hands, but of course, they 
pronounce the L, R. And then perhaps one of my

favorites is, if you spend a lot of time in Asia, 
you're familiar with bubble tea. It's this tea,

and it's got these tapioca balls inside of it. 
So there's this sign presumably at a coffee shop

and it has a little picture of the bubble 
tea and it's little eyes there and it says,

"Hi, I'm bubble tea." And then below it, it 
shows the little balls floating in the cup,

and then it says, "Suck my balls." Right? So they 
don't know what that means, right? It's all kinds

of fun, and it just points to how difficult it 
is to understand the Japanese culture, what the

Japanese are saying, and Japanese companies in 
general. Now, if you're going to start investing

there, you'll need access to the Tokyo Stock 
Exchange. It's the largest Exchange, Japan,

covers over 3,900 listed companies. They break for 
lunch, which is all rather endearing. And they go

eat Japanese food, what they call food. And let me 
tell you that the food in Japan is insane. Anthony

Bourdain said it was probably one of the greatest 
culinary manifestations on this planet. Indeed,

it is. He called it a densely packed, impenetrable 
layer cake. You wouldn't believe it. Anyways,

after you eat some amazing food, you can buy some 
stocks, and those need to be bought in round lots.

And what that can mean is that you can only buy a 
100 shares of something and that's it. They sell

them in 100 share lots. If you don't have the 
money, you don't get to buy the stock. So, that

can be problematic for retail investors that don't 
have a big enough bankroll. Also, be aware of

exchange fees. I mean, we use Interactive Brokers 
to trade stocks in Japan, and just about every

other Exchange on this planet. They work very well 
for that purpose, but you're going to be probably

charged some Exchange fees, so pay attention to 
that. And then there's the yen situation. That's

almost attractive at this point. I mean, you would 
hope the yen wouldn't sink any further than it

already has. I certainly enjoy that, but I think 
that might be a risk worth taking, in terms of

hoping that it rebounds. If it doesn't, then you 
ought to get yourself over here and start spending

some of your currency against the yen because 
it's a great place to visit. So, just some closing

comments. Japan is the largest market to invest 
in, next to the USA. Everyone should have some

Japanese exposure, along with exposure to other 
countries per the reasons that we gave today.

Regional coverage is really just that sufficient 
and many of you already have it through your 401k

funds and such. Or you could always ape Warren 
Buffett's approach or perhaps establish your own

little portfolio of Japanese stocks. But prepare 
to be underwhelmed in general. That seems to

be the way it is when it comes to investing 
in foreign stocks, many times, because they

just enjoy a valuation discount to the US, and 
that's just how it's always been and will be. And

remember that researching and following Japanese 
companies over time is very tough. Overall,

your foreign stock exposure should be roughly 
34%. So, we're going to look to cover other major

countries going forward. Now, you may have noticed 
earlier that China had a very low weighting than

intuitively it should, if you're going to use GDP 
weighting should actually be weighted much higher.

So, we did a piece looking at just at that earlier 
this year when I was in Hangzhou. We did a number

of pieces on Chinese stocks. I've put one up here 
next that proposes perhaps now is a good time to

invest in China. Give that a watch next. Thanks 
so much for taking the time to watch this today.
